captions.text:
I once did one of my characteristically insightful 
and broadly sexually arousing Semi-Ramblomatic

videos arguing that a future tentpole Mario game 
being some kind of grand open world sandbox is,

at this point, a practical inevitability, citing 
the numerous instances of Nintendo testing the

open world waters with Breath of the Wild and 
Bowser&#39;s Fury. I stand by this prediction,

but what I didn&#39;t predict was that Nintendo 
was going to make every single one of its

signature franchises go the open world sandbox 
route first. Between Mario Kart, Donkey Kong,

and now Metroid. I mean, Christ, how much 
testing does this water need? What are you,

a sewage treatment facility? Well, speaking 
of treating sewage, let&#39;s review Metroid

Prime 4. The long-awaited sequel to the classic 
Metroid Prime series that once, many years ago,

managed to cream an entire auditorium&#39;s worth 
of jeans just by slowly fading in on a logo,

but now it&#39;s fully manifested, I&#39;m afraid to say 
that may have been as high as the river of cum

was ever going to rise. I&#39;m being slightly 
cruel; I enjoyed it enough to finish it,

and it&#39;s not like I can sustain myself entirely 
on spite, whatever my school reports said.

The plot concerns famed space bounty 
hunter and Irish folk hero Seamus O&#39;Ran,

who is fighting against the evil Space 
Pirates as part of the Space Federation

military because she&#39;s still unclear on what 
a bounty hunter actually is when an ancient,

mystical artefact gets knocked off a shelf and she 
and a bunch of other nearby dudes get teleported

to a planet in a distant galaxy where a recording 
from an ancient alien race tells her she&#39;s

the chosen one destined to collect the sacred 
artefacts to help save their world from the evil,

corrupting force that they were unwise enough to 
try to exploit—Jesus, change the fucking record.

Space pirates, lonely mysterious planet, how 
many times has the Metroid series danced this

particular jive? How many ancient civilizations 
have nominated Seamus the Chosen One now? She

is to ancient prophecy what Green Day is to my 
local indie rock station. It doesn&#39;t help that,

yes, the planet has a jungle bit, a desert bit, 
a snowy bit, a volcano bit, and a tech base;

nor that most of the boss fights give me 
Metroid Prime 1 deja vu. A plant monster

with area denial tentacle attacks? A roly-poly, 
armor-plated hedgehog thing that&#39;s basically the

final exam for the side dodge move? It&#39;s just now 
instead of Phazon, the all-pervading corrupting

force is something called Green Energy. And you 
thought those windmills were just an eyesore.

But there&#39;s also a small handful of federation 
soldiers that Seamus meets across the course of

the game and gathers in home base like they&#39;re 
a fucking tea set, and they&#39;re all distinctly

characterized. There&#39;s the loner, the gruff 
sergeant, the rookie, the tech nerd who lifts his

helmet to reveal, yes, he&#39;s wearing nerd glasses 
underneath his armored faceplate that was also

made to look like it&#39;s wearing nerd glasses—and 
they all spend the game going utterly moist in

the gusset over getting to hang out with Seamus 
O&#39;Ran herself. And it made me think of another

video I made—oh goodness, I&#39;m plugging myself 
a lot today; better watch that, mum says I&#39;ll

go blind—in which I posited that perhaps silent 
protagonists don&#39;t really work in a serous context

when surrounded by distinct vocal characters. 
It feels a bit off when the other guys are still

talking at her with any amount of enthusiasm when 
she just grey rocks them the whole time. Staring

through an opaque visor behind which she could 
be rolling her eyes or blowing raspberries for

all they know. And don&#39;t get me started on when 
they start sacrificing themselves for her. Made

me think of the end of Stray. &quot;Go on without 
me! Save yourself! Remember me! Remember our

struggle!&quot; Cut to incredibly confused cat blankly 
staring as if to say, &quot;Sorry, who were you again?&quot;

There&#39;s a poor sense of who the villain is or what 
we&#39;re up against. Some dude called Sylux muscles

his way into final boss privileges, and the game 
props him up like we&#39;re supposed to give a shit

or indeed know who he is at all, but there&#39;s 
no connection between him and anything else;

all we know is that he&#39;s a space pirate who 
never speaks and his name rhymes with Sucks.

Metroids show up in only the tokenest of token 
ways. You see one during the prologue, and then

every time you scan a boss, the text description 
says, &quot;This guy&#39;s huge and got a nark on because

there&#39;s a Metroid inside him. No, we&#39;re not gonna 
show you, and he doesn&#39;t feel like coming out,

but he says hi.&quot; So the whole plot&#39;s a write-off, 
but about that open world element I was hinting

at. Basically, you&#39;ve got your traditional 
sprawling Metroidvania areas, the jungle bit,

the snowy bit, the IKEA showroom, er, Battersea 
Dogs Home, but they&#39;re all separated by a sandbox

map. And perhaps the designers took the &quot;sandbox&quot; 
brief too much to heart because it&#39;s literally

empty desert. That we have to cross every time we 
want to change areas. We are with much ceremony

given a motorbike to traverse it with. So, while 
there may be some debate over where this game

fits in the Metroid timeline, safe to assume it&#39;s 
around the midlife crisis phase of Seamus&#39; career.

And mildly cathartic though it may be to motorbike 
across a desert, it still feels more like an open

world nailed onto the side of a Metroid game as 
opposed to an open world Metroid game. We are

arbitrarily prevented from spawning the motorbike 
outside the sandbox, fun though it may have been

to do donuts around the dungeon boss&#39; lawn while 
he angrily shakes his little fist. And annoyingly,

the game also obliges us to collect the Green 
Energy Crystals that are scattered across the

desert, but they&#39;re always in groups that are 
hard to smash in a single run, so you always

have to stop and turn around to smash the ones you 
missed like we&#39;re having to go back and apologize

for splattering mud on a pedestrian, and the 
pedestrian is Hitler. But now we&#39;re on gameplay,

I need to crowbar in a discussion on the 
Switch 2&#39;s new mouse mode. For finally,

a console is able to serve up an FPS experience 
comparable to the PC gaming mouse and keyboard

control system. And in this case, &quot;comparable&quot; 
means &quot;an awful lot shittier than.&quot; Mouses—or

mice, I&#39;ve never been sure which is right; they 
both sound wrong to me—have always come in many

shapes and sizes—some curvy, some straight, some 
nestled in a mouse pad designed to look like an

anime girl&#39;s bum cheeks—but I think there&#39;s a good 
reason they&#39;ve always been thicker than a Kit Kat.

The buttons are awkward to press, and I have 
to fold my hand into a hideous claw shape to

keep it upright, so my lunchtime wank felt like 
making love to a Rolodex. I dropped it quickly,

leaving me with two control options: stick based 
or motion sensor based. Oh, could I use the stick

for large movements and then use the motion sensor 
for fine-tuning my aim? &quot;NEIN. You vill choose

either stick only and throw all motion controls 
out of ze pram or motion only and ze stick shall

sit zere doing nothing like a Protestant&#39;s 
clitoris. In accordance viz ze doctrine of

Nintendo, ze control scheme Nazi.&quot; Whatever. Like 
I said, I was content to finish the game, so take

some of this for nitpicking, but I still came away 
from the experience feeling distinctly unenriched.

Possibly because the ending sucked ass. The goon 
squad you&#39;ve assembled invite themselves to the

final boss fight and you fail if any of them die, 
so you have to keep running around resurrecting

them like it&#39;s a fucking plate-spinning act, 
and then the game tries to end with a big,

emotional finale that falls completely flat 
because neither I nor Seamus could demonstrate

the merest parceling out of shit for any of these 
twats. Sorry guys, all my shit&#39;s reserved for

now. &#39;Cause in two weeks&#39; time, I&#39;m probably 
going to have to talk about MindsEye again.
